moves.1. d4: Queen's pawn. One of my favorite openings. It usually leads to expansive and open games (which I tend to loose, but still enjoy)
moves.1... d5: Nothing strange, he replies in kind.
moves.2. c4: Queen's gambit. I love this opening, for if he accepts the gambit by playing dxe4, I'll reply with e5, immediately opting for control of the center squares and attacking his c-file isolated pawn.
moves.2... Be6:
Then he plays a strange move. Mistake by my calculation. This move is also not in the GK database. This move protects the d-pawn but it impairs development. The e-file pawn cannot advance and the dark square bishop (DSB) is blocked in.

e6 would be better do decline the gambit.
moves.3. Nc3: Developing the queen's side pieces, re-enforcing my control of the center while attacking d5.
moves.3... c6:
Protecting the d-pawn.

Another mistake, as this reduces developing options for the knight on b8.
